1: These are more proverbs of Solomon, copied by the men of Hezekiah, king of Judah.\q
2:
It is the glory of God to conceal a matter,\q but the glory of kings to search it out.
\q
3:
Like the heavens are for height and the earth is for depth,\q so the heart of kings is unsearchable.


\q
4:
Remove the dross from the silver\q and a metal worker can use the silver in his craft.
\q
5:
Even so, remove wicked people from the presence of the king\q and his throne will be established by doing what is right.


\q
6:
Do not honor yourself in the king's presence\q and do not stand in the place designated for great people.


\q
7:
It is better for him to say to you, "Come up here,"\q than for him to humiliate you before a nobleman.
\q What you have witnessed,
\q
8:
do not bring quickly to trial.\q For what will you do in the end
\q when your neighbor puts you to shame?


\q
9:
Argue your case between you and your neighbor himself\q and do not disclose another's secret,
\q
10:
or else the one who hears you will bring shame upon you\q and an evil report about you that cannot be silenced.


\q
11:
Apples of gold in settings of silver\q2 is a word spoken in the right situation.
\q
12:
A gold ring or jewelry made of fine gold\q is a wise rebuke to a listening ear.


\q
14:
Clouds and wind without rain\q is the one who boasts about a gift he does not give.

\q
15:
With patience a ruler can be persuaded\q and a soft tongue can break a bone.


\q
16:
If you find honey, eat just enoughâ€”\q otherwise, having too much of it, you vomit it up.
\q
17:
Do not set your foot in your neighbor's house too often,\q he may become tired of you and hate you.

\q
18:
A man who bears false witness against his neighbor\q is like a club used in war, or a sword, or a sharp arrow.
\q
19:
An unfaithful man in whom you trust in a time of trouble\q is like a bad tooth or a foot that slips.


\q
20:
Like a person who takes off a garment in cold weather,\q or like vinegar poured upon carbonate of soda,
\q is the one who sings songs to a heavy heart.


\q
21:
If your enemy is hungry, give him food to eat,\q and if he is thirsty, give him water to drink,
\q
22:
for you will shovel coals of fire on his head\q and Yahweh will reward you.


\q
23:
As surely as the north wind brings rain,\q so a tongue that tells secrets will result in angry faces.
\q
24:
It is better to live on a corner of the roof\q than in a house shared with a quarreling wife.


\q
25:
Like cold waters to one who is thirsty,\q so is good news from a far country.
\q
26:
Like a fouled spring or a ruined fountain\q is a righteous person tottering before wicked people.


\q
27:
It is not good to eat too much honey;\q that is like searching for honor after honor.
